bibl.title: List: Military History of Major Walter Reed, by George Miller Sternberg, [January 2, 1902]

div1.p: Sternberg lists the military posts and stations served by Reed as reported by the records of the Surgeon General.

div1.head: List: Military History of Major Walter Reed, by George Miller Sternberg, [January 2, 1902]
div1.p:
[unclear]
19928
DEPARTMENT

28
CARDED.
✓

MILITARY HISTORY of Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army,
so far as shown by the records of the Surgeon General's Office.

Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army, was appointed Assis-
tant surgeon, U. S. Army, June 26, 1875, accepted July 3, 1875,
and was on duty as follows:

At Murfreesborough, N.C., reported for duty and waiting
orders from July 3, 1875 to July 23, 1875;

En route and on duty at Willets Point, N.Y., from July 23,
1875 to April 14, 1876, during which time was on leave of absence
from Oct. 8, 1875 to Oct. 15, 1875, and from Feby. 26, 1876 to
March 6, 1876;

Reported at New York City, N.Y., general recruiting service
to accompany troops to California April 15, 1876;

En route to with recruits and on temporary duty at Fort Yuma,
California, June 1, 1876 to August 5, 1876;

En route to and on duty at Camp Apache, Arizona, from August
10, 1877 to May 10, 1880, during which time was on detached ser-
vice at Stensons Ranch, Arizona Territory, March 9 to 15, 1878 -
on leave of absence from April 2, 1879 to May 14, 1879 - in the
field from May 29, 1879 to June 3, 1879 - in the field with scouting
party from December 17, 1879 to December 23, 1879;

At Richmond, Va. En route to and awaiting orders from May 10,
1880 to June 8, 1880;
On leave of absence June 9, 1880 to August 8, 1880.

Promoted Assistant Surgeon with the rank of Captain June 26,
1880;

At Warrenton, Va., awaiting orders August 9, 1880 to August
31, 1880;

En route to Hdqrs. Department of the East for orders from
September 1 to 3, 1880;

At Creedmoor, L.I. on duty with Rifle Team from September 6,
1880 to September 18, 1880;

Awaiting orders at Hdqrs., Department of the East September 19
to 23, 1880;

En route to and on duty at Fort Ontario, N.Y., from September
23. 1880 to February 23, 1881;

At Fort McHenry, Md., on detached duty with troops and awaiting
orders from February 24, 1881 to May 2, 1881;

At Washington Barracks, D.C., from May 2, 1881 to November 17,
1882, during which time was en route to and on duty with troops at
Yorktown, Va., from October 1, 1881 to November 12, 1881.

En route to and at Hdqrs. Department of the Platte for orders
from November 17, 1882 to December 4, 1882;

At Hdqrs. Department of the Platte, Omaha, Neb., as attending
Surgeon from December 4, 1882 to January 1, 1883;

At Fort Omaha, Neb., from January 2, 1883 to October 4, 1883,
- 3 -
during which time was on leave of absence September 30, 1883 to
October 3, 1883;
At Fort Sidney, Neb., from October 5, 1883 to August 4, 1884;

At Fort Robinson, Neb. from August 8, 1884 to July 31, 1887,
during which time he was on leave of absence from December 3, 1885
to January 26, 1886. Sick at station March 6 to 18, 1886.

En route to Mount Vernon Barracks, Alabama, for duty July 31
to August 5, 1887 - at Mount Vernon Barracks, Ala., August 5, 1887
to October 6, 1890, during which time was on leave of absence Feb-
ruary 12 to 16, 1889 - on detached duty with Lieut. Cunningham 19th
Infantry to Government Hospital for the Insane December 31, 18989
to January 5, 1890. On leave of absence from September 8, 1890
to October 6, 1890;

At Baltimore, Md., Attending Surgeon and Examiner of Recruits
from October 6, 1890 to October 31, 1891, during which time was en
route to and on temporary duty at Fort Keogh, Montana, and with
troops in the field Battalion 1st Cavalry from December 16, 1890
to January 29, 1891 - detached duty Examining Board, West Point,
N.Y., June 6 to 19, 1891 - member Army Medical Board, New York
City, N.Y., October 1 to 31, 1891.

En route to and on duty at Fort Snelling, Minn., from Novem-
ber 7, 1891 to August 21, 1892, during which time was on detached
duty with Battalion, 3d Infantry, at Indian Reservation from April
1, 1892 to April 19, 1892;

At Headquarters Department of Dakota, St.Paul, Minn., as At-
tending Surgeon and Examiner of Recruits August 21, 1892 to August
31, 1893, during which time was in temporary charge Medical Director's
- 4 -
Office from March 24 to May 5, 1893, May 15 to 23, 1893, June 28
to 30, 1893, and July 1, 1893 to July 15, 1893.

En route to and on duty in Surgeon General's Office, Curator
Army Medical Museum from September 6, 1893 to date, during which
time was examined for promotion and found qualified September 1893.
Member Army Medical Board September 11, 1893 to October 21, 1893,
per paragraph 23, Special Orders 192, Adjutant General's Office,
August 23, 1893. Professor clinical and sanitary microscopy and
director pathological laboratory in compliance with General Orders
78, Adjutant General's Office, September 22, 1893. Promoted Sur-
geon with the rank of Major December 4, 1893. Member Army Medical
Board October 1 to 31, 1895, per paragraph 2, Special Orders 224,
Adjutant General's Office, September 25, 1895. On detached duty
en route to and returning from Key West, Florida, July 22, 1896, to
August 7, 1896. Member Army Medical Board September 23, 1896 to
October 27, 1896, per paragraph 7, Special Orders 196, Adjutant
General's Office, August 20, 1896; September 27, 18967 to November
6, 1897, per paragraph 1 Special Orders 152, Adjutant General's
Office, July 1, 1897; and May 2, 1898 to July 12, 1898, per para-
graph 1, Special Orders 51, Adjutant General's Office, March 3,
1898, member “Cholera” band board.

On detached duty making an inspection of camps and field
hospital August 1, 1898 to August 8, 1898. Member typhoid fever
board and to inspect certain camps August 20, 1898 to September 18,
1898. Member of board investigating causes of typhoid fever Septem-
ber 25 to 30, 1898. Same duty as above on typhoid fever board
- 5 -
October 1 to 10, 1898. Inspecting buildings at Natural Bridge, Va.
from October 18 to 25, 1898. En route to, at, and returning from
inspection duty at Puerto Principe, Cuba, from April 19, 1899 to
May 9, 1899. On detached duty at Fort Thomas, Kentucky, from
September 28 to 30, 1899. Delegate to American Public Health
Association at Minneapolis, Minn. October 31, 1899 to November 3,
1899. En route to, on duty at Tampa, Florida, and Havana, Cuba,
on investigation as to use of electrozone as a disinfectant and
germicide in Havana, and return to station March 7 to April 3, 1900.

En route to and on duty as member of board at Camp Columbia,
Cuba, investigation of diseases on island of Cuba, June 26, 1900
to July 31, 1900.

En route to Surgeon General's Office from detached duty in
Cuba, August 1 to 9, 1900. En route to and on detached duty in
Cuba relative to causes of yellow fever from September 29, 1900
to October 13, 1900. En route to United States from Havana, Cuba,
from October 14 to 20, 1900. Delegate to American Public Health
Association, Indianapolis, Indiana, October 21 to 27, 1900.

En route to and returning from detached duty in Cuba when
investigating infectious diseases prevalent on the Island of Cuba,
November 1, 1900 to February 12, 1901. Member Army Medical Board
from February 11, 1901 to present date, per paragraph 14, Special Orders
38, Adjutant General's Office, February 14, 1901. Represented the
Medical Department of the Army at the meeting of the Pan American
Congress in Havana, Cuba, February 1901. Delegate to American
Public Health Association at Buffalo, N.Y., September 16 to 20, 1901.

Surgeon General's Office,
January 2, 1902.

G.M. Sternberg
Surgeon General, U.S. Army.
